title: 114_hr3295
content:
The Department of Justice is appropriated $140,000,000 for State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance in fiscal year 2015. This includes funding for various programs such as the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant program, Drug Courts, mental health courts, programs to reduce gun crime and gang violence, and a veterans treatment courts program. The additional $10,000,000 for Juvenile Justice Programs is allocated for community-based violence prevention initiatives, focusing on public health approaches to reduce shootings and violence. This funding is separate from the State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance programs, which include various initiatives like Drug Courts and veterans treatment courts. $30,000,000 additional funding for Community Oriented Policing Services Programs, split into $15,000,000 for State law enforcement agencies in high-seizure States for precursor chemicals and methamphetamine investigations, and $15,000,000 for statewide law enforcement agencies in high opioid admission States for investigative purposes. The funds allocated for treatment admissions for heroin and other opioids will be used for investigative purposes to locate illicit activities related to the distribution of heroin and prescription opioids, and to target unlawful traffickers through statewide collaboration. INDEPENDENT AGENCIES

Small Business Administration: $4,000,000 for entrepreneurial development programs and $1,000,000 for business loans program account.

DEPARTMENT OF LABOR

Employment and Training Administration: $265,000,000 for training and employment services.

DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES

Health Resources and Services Administration: funding for maternal and child health programs. The Health Resources and Services Administration received additional funding of $50,000,000 for the Healthy Start Initiative, while the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration received $10,000,000 for substance abuse treatment. The Department of Housing and Urban Development received $170,000,000 for the Choice Neighborhoods Initiative. The Choice Neighborhoods Initiative received an additional $170,000,000 for community development fund. An additional $500,000,000 is allocated for the Community Development Fund until September 30, 2016, to aid in emergency response, recovery, infrastructure restoration, and economic revitalization in areas affected by violence or civil unrest in 2015. Funds will be granted to distressed communities lacking the capacity to recover, based on objective criteria like income levels. The curr_chunk discusses the criteria for allocating funds to distressed communities for recovery and revitalization after an unanticipated event. Grantees must submit a plan detailing fund usage and eligibility criteria to the Secretary for approval. The Secretary will specify the criteria for fund allocation through a notice. The Secretary will specify criteria for approving revitalization plans in distressed areas within 45 days of enactment. Grantees must incorporate performance requirements and penalties into contracts and subrecipient agreements for fund management. The Secretary may waive certain requirements in administering the funds. The Secretary may waive certain requirements in administering funds for contracts or subrecipient agreements, except for fair housing, nondiscrimination, labor standards, and the environment. Up to 30 percent of the funds can be used for technical assistance in immediate community response. The funds are allocated for immediate community response, recovery, and revitalization assistance. Up to $10,000,000 can be transferred for necessary costs of administering and overseeing the funds. The Office of Lead Hazard Control and Healthy Homes is allocated an additional $30,000,000 for lead hazard reduction until September 30, 2016. General provisions include moving-to-work initiatives. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will extend Moving-to-Work agreements for designated agencies until fiscal year 2028 with the same terms, except for mutually agreed changes. Agencies must report financial data for policy evaluation. The Act designates all amounts as emergency requirements, subject to the President's subsequent designation and transmission to Congress. The Act is also known as the "Rebuilding Urban Inner Cities Is Long Overdue Act of 2015" or the "REBUILD Act."
